Extract from Inspector's Report on the KITWANGA School, May 9, 1922.

Some panes of glass are needed also some new stovepipes.

R. H. Cairns,
Insp.
Ottawa, June 10, 1922.

Sir:-

Mr. Inspector Cairns, in a report on his inspection of the Kitwanga Indian Day School, states that some panes of glass and some new stove pipes are required.

As this building is rented from the church authorities, you will be good enough to draw their attention to this matter and have them arrange to supply and install the glass and stove pipes required.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

E. Hyde, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hazelton, B. C.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 20th instant, I beg to say that you may order from Clarke & Stuart, Vancouver, one Teacher's Sanitary Flat Top Desk (Fir) as listed in their catalogue as No. 456. This is the type of desk that the Department usually supplies and will cost, approximately, $30. You should arrange to have Clarke & Stuart forward you their account, in duplicate, which, upon receipt of the desk, you should certify and forward for payment.

The Department does not supply blackboard on an easel. Would it not be possible to place a blackboard on the front wall of the classroom? If so, please advise me the length and width of the blackboard required and an order will be placed.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of requisition which you forwarded from the teacher of the Kitwanga Indian Day School.

Regarding the supplying of 24 single school desks, I have to say that we will have no funds available in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year to cover the cost of this equipment. You may renew the request at the end of May or in June, next, when consideration will then be given to authorizing the expenditure required. At that time you should give full particulars as to the size and number of each size of desk required, together with full shipping directions.

The Department will approve of your arranging for the purchase and delivery of the following: 2 brooms, 1 water pail, 5 gallons floor oil, 1 mop, 1 gallon white paint, 1 alarm clock, "Big Ben" type, also, if you consider that same is necessary, you may arrange for supplying 16 lengths 6" stove pipe.

Ottawa, August 17, 1943.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.

Re: Repairs - Kitwanga Day School.

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, in which you intimate that the cost of the repairs necessary at the above-noted school will amount to approximately $127.58. Although this is substantially more than the amount we had in mind when we authorized you to proceed with this work in our letter of July 19, we nevertheless feel that the repairs should be undertaken and completed at the earliest possible date.

I must express regret that we seem to find it impossible to proceed with repairs at Indian day schools until the approach of the opening date each year. The fact that we undertake repairs from time to time with the school in operation must, of necessity, result in certain hardships and inconveniences to the teacher in charge. Would it be possible for you to circularize your agents with respect to this matter and have a list of the repairs necessary at our day schools sent forward to the Department early in June of each year? Your consideration of this suggestion would be very much appreciated.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I have your letter of August 17th and note that
the Department has approved an expenditure of $127.55 for the
repairs required at the Kitwanga Indian Day School.

With reference to the last paragraph of your
letter, I would advise that with very few exceptions there
should be no difficulty whatever in Indian Agents making the
necessary arrangements to have such repairs made during the
months of July and August. Just why some Agents fail to make
this a regular practice is difficult to understand as it is
obviously the proper time to do the work and there is usually
more opportunity for the Agent to give the necessary super-
vision then than when the schools are in session. Of course,
building materials continue to be difficult to obtain and this
may sometimes be the reason for delay in having repairs made.

It seems to me that in order to get the desired
action, this office should establish the practice of instructing
all Agents in the month of May each year to send in their
requisitions for school repairs, based on the provision made
in their annual estimates for such expenditures, and arrangements
will be made accordingly.

D.M. MacKay,

In reply to your letter of June 2nd, I wish to advise that two pieces of blackboard were received by this school and were to have been installed over part of the windows facing the pupils.

The estimated cost of installing the ceiling was also to include the blocking up of the windows and the installing of the blackboards. Due to the length of time taken by the Indian of putting in the new ceiling, entrance porch and steps, there was no money left for the windows and blackboards.

I would estimate the cost of materials and labour in blocking up the windows and hanging the blackboards about $20.00 and I would make application for this amount.

As to Mr. School Inspector Robson's recommendation for cloakroom accommodation at this school, it will be necessary to extend the school building, the cost of which might be considerable. I am therefore listing the alterations and interior decorations to the school in the 1944-45 Estimates.

With reference to your letter of April 21st, file 151-16-5 (WT 1), please be advised that the toilets at the Kitwanga Indian Day School have now been completed. It is realized that the cost of materials and labour is a good deal more than anticipated but as Kitwanga is some distance away, it was impossible to personally supervise the construction of these toilets. However, after a recent visit to the Kitwanga Indian Day School, School Inspector Davey assured me that the buildings are of excellent appearance, being sturdily constructed, painted, and roofed with proper roofing material. Vouchers covering the cost of materials are attached hereto. The two Indians employed to construct the toilets are now awaiting payment. It will be very much appreciated if you will forward to this office by airmail, an accountable advance for the sum of $84.00 to cover the cost of labour.

J. W. Boyd,

Vancouver, B.C., July 13th, 1904.

G. W. Morrow, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Metlakatla,

Dear Sir,

On behalf of the Methodist Church I beg leave to apply for a grant for the China Hat Indian Day School to you and through you to the Indian Department.

As you understand all the circumstances connected with the said school, I hope that you will be able to recommend this application to the favorable notice of the Department. Our desire is to do the best we can for the benefit of the children and should the grant be given it will be an incentive to increased efficiency in that direction.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

R. Whittington.

Sir,-

I have the honor to enclose herewith a letter, dated the 12th instant, received from Mr. Agent Morrow, of the North West Coast Agency, covering an application dated the 13th of July, 1904, addressed to him by Rev. Dr. Whittington, Superintendent of Methodist Indian Missions in B. C. for the usual grant for a teacher's salary at the Indian day school in the China Hat village. It will be observed that the Agent recommends that the request be complied with provided the Methodist Church authorities will undertake to complete the building lately erected. Sir:-

I have the honour to enclose you herewith an application in duplicate, from the Rev Dr Whittington dated July 13th/1904, requesting that the Department of Indian affairs make a grant to the China Hat Indian day school, which school is under the direction of the Rev George Edgar.

Owing to this school building not being finished on my last visit to this reserve, and having some doubts as to the attendance of children at school, I have held Dr Whittington's application pending further information considered necessary till the present time.

A short time ago I made application to the Department for a grant to purchase material, for the completion of this building, but same did not meet with the approval of the Department.

To-day I have the honour to mail you school returns which I have just received for Dec./04 and March/05 quarters, and in looking over same find the attendance fully equal to that of other small schools, in view of which, I beg to recommend that a grant be allowed this school, providing Rev Dr Whittington will undertake to complete the building, which I have no doubt he will if the grant is made and dates as in the case of the grant made to the Hartley Bay school from Oct 1st/04.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I beg to state, that, it was an error on my part, when I sent in to you last quarterly school returns ending Sep 30th 1914, for the Day school here. My daughter alone did all the teaching for the few days that the school was open after the pupils with their parents had returned from the salmon canneries.

However, I did something during that same quarter. I repaired the roof; and painted the schoolhouse throughout, and got a sufficient supply of firewood on hand to last the school for the whole of the winter.

I trust that both The Government and The church will agree for my daughter to teach the school here in my place, she was 20 years old last July, even though she is inexperienced; and has gone no further in her own studies than to pass through The Public school in Victoria. Her parents I am confident would assist her in any difficult teaching as far has we are able, so that the pupils would not suffer. Dear Sir, my reason for writing thus, is, I have been laboring among the Indians of this Province in connection with The Methodist Church nearly 27 years, and wherever I have been stationed I have had the Day school to attend to, and has a result; I must confess that my nerves are greatly shattered, my sight impaired, and I am wrecked physically. I have been sorely handicapped from infancy with my sight, I never remember seeing with one eye, and the other greatly hampered by a large cataract growing over the sight.

Dear Sir, Pardon me for writing so, but I thought it my duty.
to explain matters a little. You too, will also agree that when people are afflicted and getting on in years they are very apt to seem ingly without cause; to get irritable. Children need patient and forbearing teachers, yes. Indian children too.

Wishing you and yours every blessing and prosperity during 1915 and always,

Yours sincerely

George Read

Ottawa, May 2nd, 1924.

Sir:

Mr. Agent Fougner has recommended, at the request of the Indians, a change in the name of the Indian Village and school known as China Hat. The Indians felt that this name exposed the band to ridicule and wished to have it abolished in favour of the old Indian name of the place, viz: "Klemto". The Geographic Board of Canada, in their official report for 1917, decided the name of the village and passage to be "Klemto", after the Indian tribe. There is an entry to this effect in their report for the year mentioned, where it is stated that the village is not to be known as Klemtoo nor China Hat.

In conformity with the decision of the Board, this Department is approving of the school and village being known in future by the name "Klemto", and you should so designate them in future correspondence. We are changing the name on our files, and informing the Agent and authorities of the Methodist Church, under whose auspices the school and mission are conducted, accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLennan,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

In reply I beg to say that the Geographic Board of Canada, in their official report of 1917, state that the name of the village and Passage is "Klemtu" and not China Hat or "Klemtee". This decision shows that the board fully considered the proper spelling of the Indian name to be "Klemtu".

I would suggest that if you have any authentic information regarding the Indian spelling of this word, that you communicate with the board, at Ottawa, and supply them with the same.

Insofar as this Department is concerned, it has no recourse other than to adopt the spelling of the word as decided upon by the above named board.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

When I was with you in the month of March I promised to secure from Miss Morrice of Klemtu a statement regarding her years of service with the Department. I am therefore giving you the following extract from a letter which she has written dated April 27th. This will enable you to decide what can be done for her when she leaves Klemtu at the end of June.

"You ask regarding my years in the Indian Work.
Alberni Boarding School 1910
File Hills Boarding School 1911,12,13,14.
White Bear Indian School 1918-1919.
Kisploex and Skeena Crossing 1922-1928 (inclusive)
Klemtu 1929 up to present time.

In 1914 I left File Hills to take furlough but as I wished to get my certificate made permanent I applied to Regina to attend Normal School there. I was advised by Mr. McKechnie, who had been my teacher in Belleville High School, to take a white school for 1915 and enter Normal 1916 which I did, at close of Normal I returned to Carnbrogie as only by getting favorable report of teaching by Inspector of white school would my certificate be ratified. I taught there till close of end of 1917 and received favorable report. I was then called home to help care for my brother. Then I spent all of 1918-19 in Indian work at White Bear leaving there to have an operation on my eyes for trouble caused by looking after infected eyes at File Hills. By advice of local physician I had been using blue stone and every time the trouble returned I used bluestone, till the lens thickened and I could not see, so I had operation first on left eye and when the left eye was entirely well had one on the right eye. There being
no opening for me then in Indian work I again in 1921 taught in white school at Crichton, Saskatchewan. My brother-in-law then wrote asking me to come to my sister who was suffering from cancer. When she was some better I went to Kipling at request of Mr. Cairns and you are aware of my doings since.

Having taught steadily you might say I should have saved enough to look after myself but my two operations cost $600 (including paying two doctors and twice in hospital) my Normal cost slightly over $300 and two years ago I used all I had saved since to pay mortgage off the house or my sister with whom I make my home. My other sister got out of work just a month after I paid it off and since then Nov. 1929 I have had largely to keep them as well as pay my own expenses."

With kindest regards,

Yours faithfully,

Arthur Barner

Dear Sir:

I have the honour to forward herewith my report on the Klemtu Indian Day School, Bella Coola Agency, which I inspected on April 30th last.

I understand from the "everend R.H. McConnell," the present teacher at this school, that he is leaving the school at the end of the present school year, and that the United Church is sending him to Kitamaat as Missionary, but that he will not have any teaching work there.

This little school at Klemtu is in a very poor state from an educational point of view. It will take a well qualified teacher to pull it up to standard. If it were not that someone must be left to help the Indians here, I should recommend that the school be closed, but on consideration I believe that it would be better to build a new school and teacher's residence and appoint a married man or a young man who could act as Missionary as well as teach the school. No single girl could be sent to this village. If a Missionary could be selected whose wife was a qualified teacher we might be able to work up this school again.

Your obedient servant,

Emerald H. Barry,
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR MONTH OF OCTOBER 1940.

The Day Schools at Bella Bella, Klemtu and Bella Coola opened on the first of October and an increased attendance due in some measure to the closing of Coqualeetza has resulted in overcrowding. At Kitimat there were 64 on the roll in the beginning of October with a possible attendance of 75 which is far too many pupils for one teacher. This situation may be alleviated when certain families go down to Butedale. At Bella Coola there were 55 pupils on the roll and 48 in attendance at the time of my visit on October 24. A second room with an additional teacher is required at this point. The Bella Bella School was visited and appeared to be away to a very good start this year but one of the basement rooms will have to be utilized as a classroom in the near future employing a third teacher.

Mrs. Isobel Snodgrass has done good work at the Klemtu Indian School during the present academic year. She is a teacher of what might be termed the "old school", and her methods are somewhat harsh, but she has definitely taught the children at Klemtu more than they have learned for some years past.

I have inspected this School several times during the past seven months, and a steady progress has been noted, the response of the children to teaching has been marked, and the general tone of the school improved. Mrs. Snodgrass was asked to be less severe in her methods, and she has made an effort to co-operate.

She has had the support of the parents, who on many occasions have expressed their gratification for her services to the school and village life in general.

It is my understanding that Inspector Thorstenstein will not be able to inspect this school this academic year due to the Agency boat being laid up for repairs. I have discussed Mrs. Snodgrass's work with him, and have no hesitation in recommending that her services be retained for another academic year, commencing Sept. 1st, next, when the parents of the Klemtu children have promised to have their children ready for school attendance. This recommendation is made having in mind the extreme difficulty of obtaining qualified teachers with modern training.

REPORT ON BELLA COOLA AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF DECEMBER, 1943.

Schools:

Day schools at Bella Coola, Klemtu, Bella Bella (2 division) and the empty schoolhouse at Kitimat were all carefully inspected. Attendance is not satisfactory at all; Klemtu and Bella Coola have most unsuitable persons as teachers; and the closing of the latter school has been recommended. I am afraid that the School at Bella Bella will suffer a serious attendance lapse. War services take men and women in a wholesale manner from the villages winter as well as summer, and if the war goes on much longer, the entire social economy of these Indians will require serious review. In the old days there were at least six months in which the parents would be home; today in some villages, they are home for two weeks at kms or for a wedding or funerals; and children by the score are not attending school at all.

It is very moot point in my opinion, as to whether home life in Indian villages will ever return to its former status, and I foresee the possibility of "ghost Villages" not long hence. Just where Councils will fit in to the picture of the future is a baffling problem, and future objectives along these lines will need careful study.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BELLA COOLA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1943.

Schools; Day.

All schools in operation were visited and inspected. It is a shame that no teachers are available for Kitammat and Bella Coola. Attendance at Bella Bella is fairly good, but I am afraid that after the new year, it will take a slump as many of these people are due to go to Namu Cannery for work. The school at Bella Coola is overcrowded. Repairs have been done at Klemtu and the building at least looks clean inside. It will last until better days come and a proper unit can be put up, with teachers quarters attached. It is suggested that at Kitammat a local Indian with Grade XI standing be appointed interim teacher, to get one room going at least. He seems a fine kind of young man, and he could not be any worse than some white interim or temporary appointments at present in action.

Mr. Inspector Coleman recently visited this village with Mr. Anfield and found occasion to instruct the Indians to clean up their village in the interests of sanitation, but advises that the school buildings and surroundings were in a worse condition than any of the Indian houses and surroundings. Consequently, it is felt that the Department might authorize the expenditure requested in order to enable us to bring some pressure on the Indians to clean up their premises.

D.H. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Your 162-12-1 of May 7th to hand. A survey of the field
situation at Kletu has been made and there is no
building even remotely suitable that could be used as
a school in this village and the carrying out of the
Department's regulations re attendance of Indian child-
ren at school in Kletu will have to await the building
of a new school. The Chief and leading men have offered
the use of the Church as a temporary school but the build-
ing is quite unsuitable for such a purpose. It is as old
as the present school, lighting is bad and heating would
be a very expensive problem.

If the United Church are able to secure a suitable
teacher for this location, it is recommended that the
present building be used but that pupilage be limited to
20 children only.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Klemtu:

Mr. L. H. Mackay,

Dear Mr. Mackay,

Conditions here force me to close the school on Oct. 4. I have tried to carry on but the roofs in both places leak something terrible. To-day there was almost an inch of water in the classroom. The agent expected me to leave the first day but I thought there might be materials on the way.

I will call in at the office upon arrival - Oct. 6. I'm terribly sorry.

Faithfully,

(Ups) Ida Conroy
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa

Re: Klemtu Indian Bay School

Enclosed herewith is a copy of a letter dated October 3rd from Mrs. Ida Conroy tendering her resignation as teacher of the above mentioned day school for the reason stated. Mr. Pruden has confirmed to a certain extent that the condition of the classroom and teacherage at Klemtu is as described by Mrs. Conroy and certainly had we known this prior to her departure from Vancouver her assignment to this school would not have been recommended.

The matter of repairs to the teacherage, which is the United Church Mission House, is being attended to but as it is doubtful if we will be able to secure a teacher for this school, and in view of the fact that the construction of a new school is contemplated it is not considered that repairs to the classroom building should be carried out.

In order to recompense Mrs. Conroy in part for the unnecessary expense she was put to in travelling to and from Klemtu I should like to recommend that she be paid salary from the time she left Vancouver on Sept. 11th until she returned here on October 6th, although the actual period the school was opened was from Sept. 15th to October 3rd inclusive.

The question of the assignment of Mrs. Conroy to another school will be the subject of a separate communication.

Reverend Sir,

In forwarding the September quarter return of the Klemtu Indian Day School, Mr. Indian Agent Fougner writes, as follows:

"The Day School at Klemtu was opened by Miss Blanche Rendle, the former teacher, on September 10th. She taught for two weeks (ten days), when Miss Mabel Widsten arrived, and started work. It may be better to pay the teachers separately. Miss Rendle lives at Bella Coola, where her father is missionary."

The salary of the teacher at the Klemtu School is paid to the Treasurer of the Women's Missionary Society, United Church of Canada, and, in view of the Agent's report that the school was not re-opened until September 10th, the Department does not consider that it should be required to pay salary for the full month. Before making payment, however, I would appreciate your advising me what amount the Women's Missionary Society is allowing for salary at this school for the month of September.

In making payment, it is presumed that it will be sufficient for the Department to issue one cheque in favour of the Women's Missionary Society as they, no doubt, will settle with the two teachers concerned.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: SALARY OF MR. J.B. GLOVER,

First of all, may I explain the arrangement which we have with Mr. Glover regarding his salary. He receives his monthly cheques from Ottawa, endorses them over to The United Church of Canada and forwards them to this office. To the $900 per year which your Department pays him, we add our grant for missionary services and send the whole amount to Mr. Glover in twelve monthly instalments.

A month ago, we received from Mr. Glover two cheques which, from the dates on them, appeared to be for April and May. We wrote him regarding this as our records do not include any cheque for March. We now have his reply in which he says that the two cheques were for April and May, and that he had sent his March cheque to our office early in April. We have again searched the records both in this office and in the Treasurer's Department and can find no trace of the March payment. Will you kindly inquire into this and find out if Mr. Glover's cheque for March has been cashed?

A statement of the cheques we have received this year may be of help to you in this inquiry. They are as follows, each for $90.00:

Received in Toronto -
For December, 1937 - Jan. 7, 1938.
" January, 1938 - Feb. 2.
" February - March 25.
" March - ?
" April - June 10.
" May - June 10.
" June - July 14.

The last of these is No. B67525 and is dated June 30th.

We shall appreciate it very much if your Department can help us to locate the missing cheque.

Yours sincerely,

HC

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $178.85 for making necessary repairs to the Klemtu Indian Day School. It is noted that $84.50 will be required for labour and if an accountable cheque is needed please let me know and it will be forwarded.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I would refer to my letter of June 19th enclosing a report on Nlemu Indian Day School by Mr. B. Thorsteinsson, who was at the school on April 1st last.

I wrote to Mr. Levelton in this connection and enclose herewith his reply of May 14th setting out the various repairs necessary to bring the school into a reasonable condition until such time as it can be replaced by a new building. Also his letter of the 1st instant giving the cost of material when delivered as $67.72 which with labour at $84.50 would amount to a total of $172.22.

If funds can be provided for this purpose, I would recommend approval of the application as the school is in a very poor shape.

For D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
In reference to your letter of May 27th, No. 215-2-4586, re repairs to school at Klamath, I beg to say that I wrote several firms handling building material, both local and at Vancouver, and so far the only quotation which I have received is from the H.J. Wells Lumber Co. of Vancouver.

Their quotation is $76.25 F.O.B. deck at Vancouver, with estimated freight charges to Klamath of $1150 additional.

These quotations are subject to stocks being available and any price change which may come into effect before date of shipment.

I note that the price of all grades of lumber advanced $4.00 per M.sq at June 16th.

T.A. Swelten
A/Indian Agent
Major D.M. Hackey, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver B.C.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of Apr. 29th, No. 215-2-3991, re: Klemtu Indian Day School.

In this connection beg to advise that I have just recently returned from a trip North to Kitamaat with the School Inspector, and took this occasion to make a closer survey of the conditions prevailing at this school.

The teacher pointed out that there was a leak in the roof near a corner of the class room, and upon investigation I found that quite a number of the shingles had blown off, leaving the roof boards exposed in several places. West side of roof will have to be replaced.

The inside of the building is one big gray smudge from smoke, caused by the old stove, and before anything can be done to brighten it, the whole room, ceiling and walls will all have to be thoroughly cleaned, with a strong soap or lye solution.

There is a very high ceiling in this room, and a movable scaffold will have to be made so that the ceiling can be reached.

After a thorough washing, possibly some of the cheaper wall coverings, such as Vello, or kalsomine, can be used to lighten up the interior. There is a small entry at the front of the main class room, and part of the roof of this is also gone, and will have to be replaced, also the foundation under this is giving way, so that the front will have to be jacked up.

In the matter of the toilets, I would recommend that new ones be built, and that they be placed at least 50 feet apart. The old ones are under the same roof, and are placed so close to the class room, that it is very unsanitary.

I am enclosing a bill of material needed for the various repairs.

[Signature]

T.A. Levellon
Acting Indian agent

Ottawa,
December 10, 1943.

Mr. F.E. Anfield, Indian Agent, Bella Coola, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 29th ultimo, the Department approves the purchase of an alarm clock and broom for use at the Klemtu Indian Day School.

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter, the Department agrees that everything possible should be done to ameliorate conditions at these isolated schools, but we do not consider it advisable for us to communicate with the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada. I also regret that it is not our policy to provide radios for teachers' residences.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ontario.

Re supplies for Klemtu (Kitasu) Indian Day School.

With further reference to the requisition for supplies submitted last mail for this Indian Day School, the teacher, Mrs. Isobel Snodgrass, requested permission to buy a small clock and a broom for this school.

These items could be obtained at the local cannery store and authority is requested to purchase them, and submit bills to the Department. The broom will cost about 90 cents, and the clock, a standard alarm type about $2.75.

This teacher, Mrs. Snodgrass, a fairly elderly woman, is living alone in the old mission house. She has no radio or other means of entertaining herself, and as the village is a particularly lonely sort of place, I was wondering if the Department would care to approach the United Church Home Mission Board with the suggestion that as this worker is a nominee of theirs, and ranks as a missionary-teacher, it might be well in the interests of her welfare and mental stability to make an appeal to one or other of their Churches to supply her with a battery operated radio of not less than five tube power. It would enable her to keep up with the news of the day, and to hear the odd programme worth while. In my opinion, it is not a good thing for these missionary-teachers to be left alone without some outside interest such as a radio could provide.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 22 June 1948.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 9th June, 1948, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence on the Kletu Indian Reserve, Bella Coola Indian Agency, in the Province of British Columbia;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Kletu Indian Reserve;

That Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest . . .";

That, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $5,850.00 f.o.b. Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses;

That it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, say that authority be granted for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this building be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Clerk of the Privy Council.
SPECIFICATIONS FOR ONE-ROOM SCHOOL AND ATTACHED TEACHER'S QUARTERS TO BE PREFABRICATED BY PREFABRICATED STRUCTURES, Ltd., VANCOUVER, B.C., FOR INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH, DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES.

(1) GENERAL - Good grade Pacific Coast Fir, Hemlock or Cedar especially selected for the purpose for which it is to be used.

(2) FOUNDATIONS - One 6 x 8 ins. centre beam to be supplied for each wing of the building.

(3) BASEMENT - Basement sash, doors, stairs, beams and posts to be supplied.

(4) WATER TABLE - This to be supplied if building to be placed on full concrete foundation. If not, will not be required.

(5) FLOOR JOISTS - 2 x 10 ins. floor joists 16 ins. O.C., 2 x 10 ins. box sills, and 2 x 10 ins. bridging supplied out to length.

(6) SUBFLOOR - Shiplap subfloor to be supplied.

(7) WALLS - Walls to consist of 2 x 10 ft. to 12 x 10 ft. sections, each section faced with tongue and groove (centre match) lumber with building paper between studs and sheathing, these sections interlocked by machine grooved 4 x 4 ins. pilasters. Top and bottom plates to be dadoed to receive pilasters. Windows to be fitted into frames and equipped with sash balances, lifts and fasteners. Outside doors to be hung in sections, factory fitted and equipped with locks.

(8) EXTERIOR FINISH - (To be included in the laid down price), Rough or smooth cedar siding (to be decided by Indian Commissioner for B.C.)

(9) BARRIER PAPER - To be supplied for exterior walls.

(10) Multi-Flex roof trusses supplied with 2 x 6 ins. ceiling and 2 x 4 ins. rafters placed 16 ins. O.C., these supplied knocked down (assembly details to be in blueprint). Roof to be self-supporting and independent of bearing partitions. Roof boards to be cut to nearest 4 ft.; 3 x 4 ins. wood gutter and "V" joint scuffit, cedar shingles to be supplied.

(11) INTERIOR MATERIALS TO BE SUPPLIED(a) Studding, 2 x 3 ins. cut to length and 2 x 3 ins. plates and 1 x 3 ins. plates random length; (b) Interior doors, frame and hardware, inside door and window casing cut to fit; (c) Floor mould and base (heavy type); Ten/Test.

(12) FINISH FLOOR - 1 x 3 V. G. Fir flooring throughout the whole building with the exception of the bathroom and kitchen in living quarters which can be 1 x 3 F.G. Fir flooring.

(13) KITCHEN CABINETS - Cabinets, Ironing Board, Medicine Cabinet, complete with hardware; DUSTPROOF KITCHEN CABINET DOORS AND PLATE GLASS MIRROR ON MEDICINE CABINET TO BE INCLUDED.

(14) NAILS AND FLASHING - Sufficient finishing and common nails to be included for the site erection of the buildings. (Nails for forms not included.) One sheet of galvanized or equal flashing to be supplied.

(15) BLUEPRINTS AND ERECTION PROCEDURE - complete sets of blueprints and erection drawings to be supplied together with complete lists of materials, hardware and doors, etc.

NOT SUPPLIED - Concrete foundation, brick work, plumbing, wiring or heating facilities and paint.

(16) Included also - Blackboards complete with necessary mouldings, etc., front wood steps, rear wood steps and interior basement steps.

Re: Klemtu Indian Day School

I am enclosing herewith confirmation of my Army Signals message of today's date wherein I recommend the construction of the above mentioned building on a day labour basis under the supervision of Messrs. Widsten and Logan of Bella Bella.

We have been confronted with many difficulties in planning for the erection of this school due largely to the location of the school site. Klemtu is located approximately forty miles north of Bella Bella on a inside channel and while there is a dock at the cannery on the Reserve there is no road from the dock to the school site nor is there a road suitable for transporting materials from the beach to the site. Widsten and Logan have a self-propelled barge which with some clearing of the waterfront below the school site may be landed on the beach at that point. From there it is proposed to build a plank road up a fairly steep grade, a distance of approximately 130' to the flat on which the school is to be built. Prefabricated sections of the building and other materials will be hauled up this incline with a power winch, all of which adds substantially to the cost of the building and provision for which is made in the estimated labour cost of $5000.

In addition to this difficulty we find that the closest gravel deposit is 25 miles from Klemtu up the coast and to haul gravel this distance by barge for the purpose of putting in a cement foundation is entirely uneconomical and would increase the cost of the building by as much as $6000. We have, therefore, decided to put in a partial basement to accommodate the heating unit. This basement...
16 feet square, will be excavated to a depth of approximately four feet and cribbed with treated planking. The entire building will be erected on treated cedar posts which will be sunk a depth of four feet to hard-pan and sheeted in to ground level.

In view of the difficulty of landing material at the site and as it is not feasible to load material from the cannery dock on to the barge, we propose shipping all the materials to Ocean Falls where there are facilities for loading the barge from the dock; the item $250 barge hire will cover cost of transporting the materials from Ocean Falls to the beach at Klemtu.

We are reasonably certain that arrangements can be made with the Klemtu Cannery which is on the Reserve to provide room and board for the crew of seven men who, in a period of seven weeks can, we believe, complete the building, including interior and exterior painting. We propose to pay the foreman of the crew at the rate of $1.56 an hour which is the prevailing rate, three carpenters $1.40 an hour and four labourers at $1.10 an hour, with time and a half for overtime and double time on Sunday. Labour costs are estimated on this basis and are recommended for acceptance for the reason that we find it impossible to interest anyone else in erecting this building for us. There is absolutely nothing for the men to do at Klemtu and actually it will probably work out that we will save money by authorizing them to work overtime, thus completing the building in a shorter period with reduced maintenance costs for the crew. We will also be obliged to pay the men's fare either from Vancouver or Prince Rupert to Klemtu and return.

We have spent considerable time with Messrs. Widsten and Logan and with their foreman-carpenter, Mr. Nordin, in arranging all details in connection with the erection of this building and I am reasonably certain that we could not make more favourable arrangements, if any, for the erection of this building. The labour crew are immediately available and some of them will go to Klemtu as soon as the proposal is approved and will proceed with the installation of the basement, foundation posts, plank road, etc., and in the event that the proposal is not approved sooner I would ask that it be favourably considered immediately on receipt of this letter as the extent of our construction program is such that we cannot possibly devote more time to this project and Widsten and Logan will not wait.
indefinitely for a decision.

It is proposed to have labour costs paid from the Bella Coola Agency office and I would ask that an accountable advance of $5000 for this purpose be forwarded to Mr. Fraden at the earliest possible date.

W. B. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

November 16, 1948.

Reference:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT,

Klatsin Indian Day School.

Bella Bella Indian Day School.

We have received a letter from Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell concerning the above schools, which reads as follows:

"In my letter of July 27th outlining a proposal for the erection of the above mentioned school I advised that we proposed hiring from Messrs. Widsten and Logan of Bella Bella a self-propelled barge for transporting materials from the boat to the beach. Their account, which includes the supply of a small quantity of lumber, foundation posts, etc., and barge hire, at a cost of $750.41, has now been received.

"I would also refer to Mr. Neary's letter of August 2nd, 1947, in connection with the acquisition by the Department of building No. 5, Bella Bella Sea Plane Base, from the War Assets Corporation, and subsequent correspondence to the effect that the proposed use of this building for additional classroom facilities at Bella Bella would not be economical. Messrs. Widsten and Logan purchased a number of other buildings at the Sea Plane Base, having established a permanent marine repair shop and other facilities, and are anxious to add building No. 5 to their establishment. While I am aware that Government property may not be disposed of other than through War Assets Corporation, it has occurred to me that inasmuch as building No. 5 was purchased for school construction..."
the intent of the purchase would be complied with if the building was transferred to Widsten and Logan to apply on their account. They have offered $550 for the building as it stands and I would recommend that if at all possible permission be granted to turn the building over to them, they to assume responsibility for compliance with all the terms of the Sales Order, the $550 being applied on their account above referred to, which amounts to $768.41."

The building referred to in the above letter was purchased under authority of P.O. 23067 of August 8, 1947. It was purchased on the recommendation of Mr. Acting Indian Agent Findlay and our District Inspector of Indian Schools. Efforts to have this building moved proved unsuccessful. We arranged for an engineer from the Lands and Development Services Branch to inspect the building and he in turn recommended taking the building completely apart as the only practical method of removal. Mr. Bills advised that it would appear questionable whether, if the building were demolished and the material salvaged, much of such material could be economically utilized in a standard building.

Could we please be advised whether authority can be issued to sell this building to Messrs. Widsten and Logan of Bella Bella, as indicated in Mr. Arnell's letter.

Bernard F. Hardy,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Klemtu School Construction

Reference is made to my Army Signals message of July 29th last and letter dated July 29th, outlining a proposal for the erection of the above-mentioned building, wherein labour costs were estimated at $5,000.00, plus additional $500.00 or 10% for supervision.

It was intended at that time that construction of the building would be carried out under the supervision of Messrs. Widsten and Logan, of Bella Bella, but it consequently developed that they themselves could not supervise the project and they turned the matter over to their foreman-carpenter, Mr. E. Nordin. The 10% for supervision is, therefore, payable to Mr. Nordin, who arranged for the employment of labour, receipt of materials at the site, etc., and actually assumed full responsibility for completion of the building.

We have been awaiting receipt of full information from Mr. Pruden with regard to labour costs, which information is now to hand, reference his Credit Voucher No. 89 attached, and previous Credit Voucher No. 866, already submitted. On the basis of this information, the attached Voucher No. 28, in the amount of $475.89, payable to Mr. Nordin, has been prepared in this Office and is recommended for payment.

It should be noted that Mr. Nordin's percentage is based on gross wages paid to carpenter's helpers only up until the
date they left Klemtu (November 2nd) and although some minor construction was carried on after that date, it is not considered that any percentage of labour costs incurred after Mr. Nordin left Klemtu would be payable to him. Also excluded from the total of labour costs from which the percentage is computed, are costs for labour not actually engaged in the construction of the building.

It is felt that this settlement should be satisfactory to Mr. Nordin and I would ask that a cheque in his favour be forwarded in care of this Office.

[Signature]

for W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Mr. W. S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Klentu School Construction

Mr. Levelton has returned from Klentu and reports as follows. The carpenter and painter were paid off and left Klentu October 27th. Mr. and Mrs. Norlin are remaining another week to complete plumbing. All fares have been paid to Vancouver. Mr. and Mrs. Norlin are paid up to and including October 27th.

Mr. Levelton wired you advising that the teacher not leave Vancouver until November 5th. No coal had yet arrived. The wood had not been put in as had been promised and as the Chief Councillor was away no assurance was possible when the wood would be put in. It is expected that Chief Councillor Brown will be in the village by today, as he has always been most co-operative, I am sure he will make every effort to have the wood put in. The man who had promised to do this work had subsequently been employed by Mr. Norlin to help with the plumbing. I have wired Chief Councillor Brown as follows:

"Have wired teacher to stay in Vancouver until coal and wood are in school cellar. Wire me when coal has arrived and wood is cut and stored."

The following wire has gone forward to you:

"Levelton reports no fuel Klentu. Have wired council to notify me when fuel is in. Suggest Roylands remain Vancouver until further notice from here. Letter in mail."

Mr. Levelton's wire to you from Klentu noted items missing from plumbing. Drain assembly for bathtub had not yet arrived from Hock, Oregon & right as asked in my wire of October 16th. Flange for toilet bowl with bolts for attaching same were found not to be in the order when it was unpacked. Quarter bend for three inch soil pipe, this item was not included in my original order by an oversight. Lead stub three inches by eleven inches long to connect from toilet flange to soil pipe 3/4" threaded pipe elbow. These were found necessary when Mr. Norlin commenced to lay out plumbing. One 3/4" compression stop. This is for drain to range boiler which was not provided.

The following items of household equipment had not yet arrived. Window shades throughout, draperies throughout, curtain rods throughout, towel racks, coal oil bracket lamp for bathroom, triangle dust mop, wet mop, set of table cutlery or flatware. The last item is the most important since housekeeping would be difficult without table flatware. The other items could come forward later. No doubt there will be other necessary items which I have missed in my order.

Mr. Norlin considerably underestimated the time it would take to finish the job when I was last at Klentu. I had serious doubts myself that he could finish by the 27th. He however reiterated this date so definitely to my second questions on the subject that I could only take his word for it. I believe possibly his men were wearying after the long continuous work period and probably did not respond during the last week as he had hoped. He has now hired two Indians to assist with digging, etc. during the final stages.

There is now $142.65 left in the wage account. I will hold this to pay the Indians and hope it will prove sufficient. I had hoped to complete the installation of the plumbing within the $5,000.00 sent here to pay wages. Plumbing was not of course originally estimated within that figure. However had the rise in wage rates not intervened since estimates were prepared, the plumbing could have been included.

OTTAWA, June 9, 1948.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL:

Requesting authority for the provision of a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence on the Klantu Indian Reserve, Nellie Coolea Indian Agency in the Province of British Columbia, for which funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates.

Two extra copies of Order-in-Council are required.
June 9, 1946.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1945-46 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence on the Klondu Indian Reserve, Bella Coola Indian Agency, in the Province of British Columbia;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Klondu Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides in part as follows:-

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest . . . .";

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $5,850.00 f. o. b. Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses.

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.

Further to my 1-1-3 of January 31st, reference your file 1-11-3, attached is voucher 166, supported by labour returns covering the work done by Mr. Peder Holland up to January 8th. I have put in fifty-three cents to make up enough to cover wages and L. I. O. contributions for the period. The accountable advance for labour has now been fully expended.

The following labour returns remain unpaid:

Mr. Peder Holland for week ending Jan. 14th total $44.42
" " " " " " " 2nd " " " " " " " " 30.35
" " " " " " " 20th " " " " " " " " 24.89

Work ceased on January 27th because heavy frost made the finishing of the outside work such as setting septic tank and digging drain from outside toilets uneconomical. This work will be resumed as soon as the ground has thawed and it is estimated that about $50.00 will complete it. To cover unpaid labour returns and cover the estimated work to complete this construction I will require about $100.00.

I had fully expected that the period to January 22nd would complete the work. Mr. Holland has been supplying me with a daily account of each day's work and I notice the following items which I believe readily account for the extra time spent:

1. The solder work on the plumbing was not satisfactory. The system had to be drained several times in an attempt to repair leaks.

2. On January 2nd a shipment of galvanized piping arrived from Gordon & Holmes. This was doubtless a duplicate of an earlier order. Mr. Holland considered it wise to replace some of the copper pipe where leaks still persisted with the galvanized piping and threaded joints with which he was more familiar. This carried the work up to January 14th.

3. Kitchen woodwork, which I had noted was unfinished, occupied the next two days.

4. On January 15th it was found that the hot water tank would not heat in the bathroom where it had been placed. It was disconnected and moved to the kitchen where it worked satisfactorily. This brought the work to January 16th.

5. Four and a half days the following week were spent in clearing and building bases. This was necessary to provide a place to pile fuel which I had ordered put in and to clear a route for the train from the outdoor toilets.

6. Three days of the following week were spent in finishing and painting woodwork inside the building.

The work remaining which awaits thawing of the ground, includes connecting the septic tank. It will be recalled that I am doubtful that this tank will work in the shallow pit where it is now installed. This point remains in doubt.

Dear Sir,

Would you kindly send me the last Indian Report for 1868? I must thank you for former favors along this line; and can assure that I greatly appreciate your kindness.

I do not know whether Dr Whittington has written you or not regard to our schools at this place. It seems very peculiar to me, that the Roman Catholics, with much smaller schools than ours, should be receiving government grants, whilst our schools are receiving none. If our schools were in the same villages as theirs I might understand it; but in no way whatever does our schools interfere with theirs. One of our schools is on the Quamichan Reserve where two thirds of the people petitioned for it, some three years ago. The Roman Catholics have never had a school. The other school is on the same facts apply as in the Quamichan case.

Both of our schools are regularly inspected by Mr Green, and results of his inspection duly reported to Ottawa. If there is any formal requirement not complied with, I would deem it a favor if you let me know what it is.

Report of Inspector R.H. Cairns on the Koksilah Day School.

For six months of the year the attendance is fairly good. There is some chance to make progress. English is not used in the homes and so slow progress is made in acquiring English. The matter of erecting new buildings is under consideration. A school house, a chapel and a residence for the teacher are contemplated. Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a communication from the Indian Agent informing me of a communication which he had received from the Department, and from which the following is an excerpt:

It is noted by the returns that this school—Koksilah—was only open forty-two days in the month of June quarter, closed during the entire March quarter, was only open four days during the December quarter last, and six days in the September quarter last, etc., etc.

It is only just to myself that I be permitted to make a personal explanation, and to disclaim any personal responsibility for the conditions cited. September quarter is always a difficult one in which to have school at all. The Indians leave here in August for the hop picking, and do not return as a rule until the last of September. It is usually the last week in September before there are any pupils here to open school with. December quarter was closed the entire quarter, with the exception of the six days mentioned, by order of the M.H.O. for the district on account of Influenza. The ban was not lifted until well on in January for the school. During the entire March quarter and until after Easter in the June quarter I was so ill that it was quite impossible that I should have re-opened the school. As a matter of fact I reopened the school for the sake of getting it going again, although in no condition of health to do it.
I have no authority to engage a substitute while ill, and could not have possibly attended to it even if I had.

I quite recognize the fairness of the attitude of the Department, and agree with them that the school should be kept open whenever children are here to attend it. I think if you will investigate my record for the past several years you will see that I have always been faithful in the discharge of my duties, and that the school has never been closed through any neglect on my part.

I simply wanted to make this explanation as it is not a pleasant thing to face during the coming year, that there should be any feeling of dissatisfaction with my personal actions in the discharge of my duties.

Yours very truly,

C. A. Stockstader
Methodist Missionary.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge yours of the 17th ultimo, referring to the education of the Indian children on the Cowichan reserve. I have noted that there are 80 children of school age in the Quamichan, Comoxaken, Ahnapson, Clamalamute, Somence and Koksilah bands.

As you may know, at one time there were two day schools for the Quamichan band, under the auspices of the Roman Catholic and Methodist churches. These were closed in 1917 and 1912, respectively, because of poor attendance. There was a Roman Catholic school for the Somence band which met a similar fate in 1910. There remains now the one Koksilah Indian Day School, with an average attendance of about 10.

I have noted that you have made a careful study of the educational needs on the Cowichan, and the Department is giving earnest consideration to your suggestions. As soon as funds can be provided we will endeavour to build a day school on the north of the river, between the Quamichan and Comoxaken bands. You might inform the Department if we own any school buildings in the vicinity and if any school equipment, such as desks and blackboards, is available. The Department's policy is to allow a church to have the supervision over these day schools, and it is thought that this school to the north of the river should be conducted under the Roman Catholic auspices.

For the requirements of the children to the south of the river, you have recommended the moving of the Koksilah Indian Day School. In reply I wish to state that we have taken up with the Methodist Church authorities the advisability of moving their school to a point near the Koksilah railway station. I believe it would be advisable to have it continue under their auspices. Would you give an estimate of the cost of moving this building and intimate to the Department if its condition would permit of such moving. I understand that it was erected in 1916 and is the property of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Reverend Sir:

I have to acknowledge yours of the 17th ultimo, referring to school matters on the Cowichan reserve, Vancouver Island. In the past the education of the Indian children of the Quamichan, Somenos and Koksilah bands has met with little success, due to poor attendance. Four Indian day schools, two Roman Catholic and two Methodist, have been in operation from time to time. At present there is but one school in operation, the Koksilah Indian Day School, under the auspices of the Methodist church.

Mr. Agent Lomas, of Duncan, B.C., feels that there should be two Indian day schools on the Cowichan reserve and that one should be built on the north side between the Quamichan and Comoxen bands for the Indian children north of the Cowichan reserve; the Khemispson and part of the Clemclemalute bands would have access to this school.

The Indians south of the river could send their children to the Koksilah Indian Day School if it were moved to a point near the Koksilah railway station. Then it could cater to the needs of the Somenos and Koksilah bands and to the Quamichan and Clemclemalute who live south of the river.

In view of our agent's report, will you investigate, on behalf of the Methodist Missionary Society, the advisability of moving the Koksilah Indian Day School to a point near the Koksilah railway station. This matter should be attended to without delay, as Mr. Agent Lomas claims the building is in danger of being washed away during high water.

I might add that as soon as the Department can build north of the river, the Roman Catholic church will be asked to secure a teacher, as they have a strong cause at this point.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

MEMORANDUM REGARDING THE REQUEST OF MR. AGENT LOMAS TO PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES FOR THE RESERVES IN THE CONICHAH AREA.

Quamichan Reserve:
There were formerly two Indian schools in operation on this reserve, viz: the Quamichan day school under the auspices of the R.C. church and the Cowichan under the auspices of the Methodist church. The R.C. school was closed June 30, 1917. The Indians were away from the reserve from April to October of each year and there was a very poor attendance during the winter months. The Methodist school was open for a few years. It was closed June 30, 1912, on account of poor attendance.

Somenga Reserve:
A school was opened on this reserve in 1900 and carried on under R.C. auspices. It was closed in 1910 on account of want of interest on the part of the Indians and the poor attendance.

Koksilah Reserve:
There is at present a school conducted on this reserve under the auspices of the Methodist church. There is an enrolment of 18 and an average attendance of 9. The teacher, Janet H. Gibson, is paid a salary of $750 per annum.

There have never been schools on the Comeaken, Khenipson, or Clamclemaluta Reserves.

The latest census returns available are for the year 1916, but it is noted that the agent states there are approximately 80 children of school age on the above reserves. They belong to the Methodist and R.C. denominations.
Sir,

I have the honor to report the following matter for your information and advice, in regard to the education of Indian children in this Agency, adjacent to Duncan and embracing the Quamichan, Comoxen, Thompson, Clonelalute, Soquenos and Koksilah Indian Reserves.

In this area there are approximately eighty children of school age, and the only school being the Koksilah Day School with an average of twenty pupils, and average attendance of nine. The reason of the small attendance being that this school is situated on an isolated corner of the Reserve, rendering it impossible to get a greater attendance owing to the great distance the children have to walk.

It seems to be imperative that if the children on the above Reservations are to receive an education that a new day school will have to be built at a point to be decided upon, between Quamichan and Comoxen Reserves, on the north side of the Cowichan River, which would give access to the Comoxen, Thompson, part of the Clonelalute children and those on the Quamichan Reserve lying to the north of the river.

I understand that the Methodist Mission Society are about to approach the Department with a view of having the Koksilah Indian day School moved to a point near the Koksilah Railway Station, which would then give access to part of the Clonelalute, the Soquenos, and Koksilah bands and those on the Quamichan reserve, lying to the south of the Cowichan River.

I have made a careful study of this question, and should like to most strongly point out to you, that if the Department see fit to build a new school and move the Koksilah school, that qualified teachers be appointed and that they be absolutely non-sectarian and that no religious instruction be allowed in the schools during school hours.

My reasons for suggesting this are, that in a scattered area as this, that we must insist upon the children attending the school within their reasonable reach, irrespective of their religious followings, and I feel certain that should the Department carry out something along these lines, that both the Protestant and Roman Catholic Institutions would be agreeable.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

A few days ago the Reverend Father Scheelen, the Reverend Mr. Gibson, and Mr. R. H. Chirnside, Inspector of Indian School for B.C., called at my office in regard to schools etc.; I made the suggestion that no religious instruction should be given during school hours; to this I think I can safely say that they were agreeable, and to me it seems the only way of getting the children educated and avoiding the long standing grievance that now exists.

Under this head and having regard to the present Komilik Indian Day School, I should like to point out to the Department that this school is in danger of being washed away yearly during high water. It is situated on an island in the Cowichan River, consisting of about two acres, and during the high water in November last, a considerable portion of the Island was washed away, and the bridge over which the children cross to school was also washed out.

The question might be asked why most of the children are not sent to the Kuper Island Industrial school; to this might I say, that this school is at present practically full to its capacity, and I am sorry to say that over fifty per cent of the pupils being from outside this Agency.

Sir:

Dear Sir,

Regarding the Day Schools at Quamichan and Koksilah, B.C.:

I understand the Department has been considering making these two schools denominational. Inasmuch as the Roman Catholics and the Methodists are the two religious bodies concerned and for some time past the only school operated for the two Reserves being at Koksilah under the management of the Methodist Church, I would agree to the proposal of undenominational schools being established providing a Roman Catholic teacher is engaged for the Quamichan children and a Protestant teacher engaged for the Koksilah Reserve.

In agreeing to this arrangement we do so with the hope that all Protestant children on the Quamichan side will attend the school with the Roman Catholic teacher, and that all Roman Catholic children on the Koksilah side will attend the school with the Protestant teacher.

Honorable Sir:-

May I direct the attention of the Indian Department to the following:

At a meeting held at Duncan, B.C., Mr. Russell Ferrier presiding, it was decided that a Catholic school be built at Komiaken for the children residing on the Komiaken, Ghenepson, Tlemlimilite, Quamichan reserves.

It was also proposed that the present Konsilah school -- until now under the auspices of the Methodist Church -- be made either a public school with no religious instruction or a neutral school with religious instruction to be given at stated times after school hours by priest or minister to children belonging to their respective denominations --- this proposed change to be made, as of the eighteen children on the school roll, only six are Methodists, or claimed to be so by the Methodist missionary, the remaining children being Catholics.
The approval of this proposition was left to the decision of His Lordship, the Bishop of Victoria. With regard to this school, may I add that the Koheilah school was built under false pretenses. At the time of the erection, only a small number of the children on the roll were Methodists, and there was no prospect whatever of an increase in the future, as time has proved. Again this school was built, the local Indian agent not even having been consulted, as Mr. Robertson can testify. Again it was built in an out-of-the-way part of the district, hardly accessible, necessitating the building of a bridge to reach the school; this bridge has already been swept away by the floods of the Cowichan River, and so will the -- sooner or later -- the school itself. Mr. Ferrier will give you a verbal detailed report on this.

May I ask the Department that a school under Catholic auspices be built next spring on the Somenos reserve near Duncan. On that reserve there are today 21 (twenty-one) children of school age, all Catholic children, of those only five or six attend at times the Koheilah school. Again, these same children are continually exposed to danger; for to reach the school they are forced to climb over half a dozen fences, cross the railway track and the railway bridge. In case of accident, who will be held responsible?

May I ask the Department that the Koheilah school be made temporarily a strictly public school with no religious instruction whatever; for we hope also to get one day a Catholic school around Koheilah. I trust to receive a favorable reply.

Yours,

[Signature]

I enclose the foregoing application.

Alexander Macdonald
Bishop of Victoria

Dear Sir,

Father Scheelen, an old missionary to the Cowichans Indians, and now a resident of Saanich B.C., told me that on the 17th of July 1925 he himself made an agreement with Mr. Gibson, at that time Methodist Minister at Kokilah, by which both of them were entitled to go and teach religion to the children of their respective church, at the Kokilah school after school hours. Both of them agreed to this, because, if I am not mistaken, there were not enough Methodist children to keep up the school and also because it was impossible to the Government to grant a needed Catholic school at Somenos and Kokilah.

The agreement was oral. It was made in the presence of Mr. Perrier, Mr. Cairns and Mr. Lomas, in the Indian Office at Duncan, on the above mentioned date.

As Mr. Graham does not think that he can rely enough on Father Scheelen's testimony to let me act according to the agreement, I am trying to locate records of this agreement. In the Indian Office, at Duncan, the records show that the meeting took place on the above mentioned date, and that were present all those mentioned by Father Scheelen; but no record is to be found of the agreement. Nothing also in Victoria.

As the agreement was not official, but was agreed to, if not suggested by Mr. Perrier, the only place where it could be recorded, would be in Mr. Perrier's diary.

Mr. Graham agreed that as long as the agreement was never official, it would be better not to make any official request for its acknowledgment. He left it entirely to me to write to you and ask if there is any record or the agreement in your office.

Trusting that you will give this matter your kind attention, I am adding a few words, yet more personal. Best wishes to you and your family, from a young priest, you have met at Nuper Island during your last visit.

Dear Mr. Graham:

Re- the Department letter dated January 3, 1936, No.152-8A-1 allowing religious instruction for Roman Catholic pupils at the Kekalak Indian Day School.

Aside from the Lord's Prayer in the morning religion has not been a part of the school curriculum. Up to date there has been no difference made between children of the different denominations and it is probable that with the introduction of these classes some difficulties may arise.

These instructions would be given after school hours meaning the Roman Catholic children would have to remain an extra hour until four o'clock. Seeing the majority of the children live at a distance of approximately two miles from the school it would mean them getting home very late. This instruction would be a drawback to the school routine. The school must be cleaned and the work for the following day prepared and put on the blackboard. When could this be done if the classroom was in use after school?

I trust that some arrangements can be made where a class can be held that would not conflict with the school routine.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF MR. G. H. BARRY, INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS, DATED MARCH 31, 1936, ACCOMPANYING HIS REPORT OF INSPECTION OF THE KOKSILAH INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

I have the honour to forward herewith my report on the Koksilah Indian Day School, Cowichan Agency, which I inspected this morning, March 31st. Previous to my inspection I had a long conference with Mr. Indian Agent Graham with regard to the Indian day schools in his agency, and particularly with regard to the Department's instructions relative to the giving of religious instruction by the local Catholic Priest at this Koksilah Indian Day School. This conference took place yesterday, but I had to wait till this morning to inspect the school as the teacher was ill yesterday and could not go to school.

After my inspection of the school this morning I met the local United Church Missionary for a few minutes.

Very good progress is being made at the Koksilah Indian Day School, and I have every reason to think that the good work being done by Miss Creighton will continue. While she was not entirely happy with regard to the giving of religious instruction after school by the Catholic Priest, as it involved some changes in her usual procedure of cleaning the school, etc., I am quite confident that the Department's instructions will be properly carried out. I am very pleased that this matter of instruction for the Catholic children has now been arranged for as mentioned in my report. My inspection this morning was mainly with a view to seeing just what arrangements had been made to comply with the Department's instructions in this matter.
Re Religious Instruction at the KOKSILAH DAY SCHOOL.

Answering my letter of the 8 Jan., Mr. Phelan on the 13 Jan., 1936, sent me a copy of a letter to Rev. J. Welch, Ottawa, Sept. 18, 1922, regulating the matter. Here again, I would like to have a few informations. The letter says that "the school should be conducted along the undenominational lines". Is there any positive rules made by the Department regarding such schools or are rules made for each case.

The actual teacher is having the Lord's prayer said, thus following what is done in the schools of the Province. Is that according to the agreement? This matter was referred to the local Agent, who apparently could not reach any decision.

P. S. - Religious instructions at Koksilah. I have been going there after school hours. But I noticed that children are not very willing to stay after school time. Moreover the teacher is taking some children home in her car; of which ride they are deprived when they have to stay. The situation would be worse yet if general transportation was practised. So, if the agreement regarding religious instruction could stand for, I would ask for a certain time during school hours.

Dear Sir:

Here is my answer to your question of whether or not the actual agreement for religious instruction to the catholic children, attending the Kokeilah School, is meeting with my approval.

As you remember, the actual arrangement was accepted, only because we could not agree on the meaning of the agreement. But it was understood that the matter could be brought up again.

I have noticed that this arrangement, is not enabling me to reach all the children of the Catholic Faith, as the younger ones are entitled to leave the school before that time, and as I can not see that it is the duty of the teacher to keep those children in school after the regular time.

Furthermore it still seems to me, that according to the text of the agreement, one would be entitled to "an hour", during the regular School Time.

I therefore ask for an arrangement, that would realise the purpose of the agreement, which is to enable the Catholic Priest and the United Church Minister to give religious instructions to all the children of their respective Faith.

Regarding the point of the agreement, concerning the teacher, I am not asking to have it put into effect at present.

Trusting that this statement will answer the purpose of the inquiry by the Department, I would ask you to send a copy to the Secretary of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Moore,

In reply to your letter of April 28th, re the children other than Indians attending the Koksilah Indian Day School, I am permitting four children to attend.

Three of them are Chinese, Pansy (age 14) Poppy (age 12) and Oswald (age 10) Hop Wo children of a Chinese farmer, who, I believe, renting land on the reserve. The other one is Irene Georgeson (age 10) halfbreed daughter of Mr. Wm. Georgeson of Saanich, B.C., and whose mother (deceased) was a Koksilah woman.

I have admitted these children by verbal consent of former Indian Agent, Mr. Graham, with the understanding that they should obtain their own supplies, and in no way be dependent on the department. This has been strictly followed, and they are in no way hindering my work with the Indian children.

These four children are all attending with a good reason. Mr. Georgeson felt that since Irene was more Indian than white, and that for her own happiness and progress in work, she would be better in an Indian school. She is a bright happy youngster, has brought her own books and desk so as to be able to attend. She is no trouble in discipline or attendance. I feel she is a decided help in the class.

The Chinese children are attending because they are so far from the white school. They, also, have brought their own books and desks. They are very keen pupils and have had almost perfect attendance. I find that they provide enough competition in class work to spur the Indian children on to more neat and accurate work. I find the Chinese and Indians get along nicely socially, and I think it is good for the Indians to meet children of another race. It brings up many lessons in good sportsmanship.

Personally I would like to keep them as pupils in this school, for they are not taking up any more of my time during school hours, using supplies, or taking up any desks supplied by the
Department for the Indian children, but they are, in my opinion, an asset to this school.

Trusting that this information is satisfactory,

Very sincerely yours,

"Florence L. Perry"
