Dear Sir:

Indian Agent R. H. Moore, in his monthly report on the Cowichan agency, states:

"One matter which concerns me a great deal is the matter of White and Chinese children attending the day schools on the Cowichan Indian reserve. These children are the offspring of some of the renters of this reserve, but why their renting privileges should include the education of their children is beyond me. I understand that the Department has knowledge of this and approved of it on certain conditions, but I wish to bring the question to your attention again. I will give the whole question careful study during the next month and if I feel that there should be a change in the policy I will so advise."

I was somewhat disturbed to learn that there are White and Chinese children attending Indian day schools in the Cowichan agency. There is nothing on file here to indicate that the attendance of these children was approved by the Department at any time. In any event, it is exceedingly difficult to administer day schools at which White and Indian children are enrolled. There always appears to be difficulty with respect to attendance, the payment of fees for tuition, etc.

The Indian school population of the Dominion is increasing at the rate of approximately 300 pupils per annum, and we are finding it very difficult indeed to secure the funds necessary to provide accommodation for the Indian pupils of the country. In view of these facts,

Dear Sir:

In your letter you state: "These reports are all favorable to these children continuing at Koksilah, and under the circumstances it might be well to permit them to do so."

I was not aware of departmental letter dated June 1, 1933, in which permission was granted a Chinese boy to attend the Koksilah school. In any event, this letter should not be interpreted to mean that white or Chinese children are permitted to attend Indian day schools, unless their attendance has been authorized by the Agent, and in the case of British Columbia, by the Indian Commissioner.

You are no doubt aware that a year or two ago a regulation was approved by the Minister and passed, whereby half-breed children are no longer eligible for enrolment at residential schools. In view of this regulation, white or Chinese children should not be encouraged to attend our schools, except in exceptional cases and then only on the recommendation of the agent, approved by yourself. It has occurred to me, also, that it might be well to have this recommendation in the case of each school approved at the beginning of each academic year.

Dear Mr. Moore:

Re: Janet Williams

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant in reference to the above named pupil.

Replying to your request for information on Janet's previous education I would say she runs a poor chance of covering in a satisfactory manner the work required for Grade Eight.

As St. Catherine's School follows a Vocational Training program, the time allotted to class work is naturally limited. Therefore, a pupil of Grade Eight standard in this school cannot compete with pupils following the B.C. Program in preparation for high school. Moreover, this school operates only eight months a year.

While Janet has a good head she is wanting in perseverance. She figures well in arithmetic, grammar, spelling and art but lacks background in social studies, literature and science.

In her letter of application for transfer she states that I told her that she would have to buy her own books if she took eighth grade. This is a misleading statement. These books could have been requisitioned had she expressed a desire at an earlier date to study for high school but since she began only at the end of October there would have been no choice left but to purchase the books required for the grade.

Knowing from experience the work and time required to prepare pupils for high school entrance I cannot see my way clear to put Janet through starting at this late date and closing school in May.

Sincerely yours,

Re: Virginia Jones, Tsaycum Band, 14 years.

I have just had a visit from the above noted girl who was a pupil at St. Catherine's Indian Day School last year, for permission for her to transfer to Koksilah Indian Day School. The facts of the case follow:

While this girl is a member of the Tsaycum Band, her mother was a Cowichan girl who married into the former Band, but only lived with her husband for 3 months. Apparently the marriage took place when the girl was under age and the necessary consent of her parents was not received. At all events, the child has lived most of the time with her grandmother on the Cow. I.R., and originally attended the Koksilah School. Later she went to live with the grandparents on the father's side and of course had to leave Koksilah school owing to the fact that she was a Catholic was sent to Kuper Is. Res. School. The next year she returned to the Cow. I.R. and on account of her religion I told her that she would have to go to St. Catherine's school, which she did last year. Now, she has just returned to the Cow. I.R., after being away fishing and wants to go to the Koksilah School because the school is only ½ a mile away from her present home and her half brother and cousin attend Koksilah School and go home at noon hour for their lunch or dinner, and her grandmother wants this granddaughter to do the same so that they will all get their dinner in the middle of the day. I don't usually refer these matters to the Dept. as I tell the Indians that they cannot change schools. However, I think an exception could be made in this case and as she is not the only Catholic attending the Koksilah School, which is actually non-denominational, I cannot see where there would be any harm in having all the children from the same house attend the same school. Please advise.

REPORT ON GOWICHAN INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1944.

Schools are quite well attended generally, although in some instances attendance of some of the older pupils are inclined to be irregular. This can be accounted for by the fact that there is so much work available for teen age boys and girls in the canneries that they try and sneak in for a day or two each week, or work after school hours and then forget to get up out of bed the following morning. There are so many day schools now that it takes up a great deal of time and delays the other work of the agency accordingly.

Dear Sir:

The three children of Richard Thorne, Gordon, Charlotte and Gladys, I have been informed, are now attending the Kwikwetlem Indian Day School with the approval of the Department after they had been registered at St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

To say the least, I find this approval very strange. These children are R.C. from R.C. parents and according to the Indian Act should attend a school of their denomination. As they have lost their Mother, the normal place for them would have been River Island Boarding School. And if no place was available for them presently, they should have returned to St. Catherine's.

I am aware of the fact that they are living with their uncle Chuck Thorne, and that he has the right to request their transfer. The reasons put forward, in my estimation are of a negligible nature, and if the Department allows transfers on such grounds, from one school to another, especially as is the case of R.C. children to a non-denominational school, the Department is surely giving occasion to difficulties of all kinds, and complicating in no small measure, the education work amongst the Indians.

I would therefore appreciate it if you would ask the Department for a reconsideration of the matter, and for another decision.

Yours truly,

Lucien D. Leclair

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing the resignation of Miss Maud Barner as teacher of the Koksilah Indian Day School, to take effect at the end of the present academic year, viz.: June 30th, and enclosing an application from Miss Josephine Archibald for the position, together with a recommendation from Rev. Arthur Barner.

In reply I have to say that the Department will accept the resignation of Miss Barner, to take effect on the date mentioned.

Relative to the appointment of Miss Archibald, it is noted that she has a Second Class Nova Scotia Teacher's License and has had several years' experience. The Department will approve of her appointment, to begin duties when the school re-opens after the summer holidays next. The total salary allowed her will be at the rate of $95.00 per month for the ten teaching months in the year. We note that, as it is necessary for the teacher to board at the Methodist Mission, the missionary and his wife will board and lodge Miss Archibald.

We are informing Mr. Inspector Cairns of the approval granted for the appointment of Miss Archibald.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Alfred H. Lomas, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B. C.
To Mr. Boomer
Dept. of Indian Education

Sir,

I wish to draw your attention to what appears to be a great hardship and injustice to the teacher at this place and no doubt what I may have applied to all schools working under the same plan.

It is a question of the paying teachers quarterly instead of monthly, as are public schools do in B.C.

Our Teacher (Miss Boomer) taught April, May and June when the school closed for summer holidays. From June 1st to the 16th of August she has not yet received her salary. Therefore she has not been paid for work done in April, May, and June, a long time for a girl to have to wait for her pay.

As you know Miss Boomer has left us, but another teacher has been appointed. I will start on Sept. 1st at the end of that month she will receive one month's salary and nothing more until Jan. 1926.

Could the teacher still be paid quarterly? I worry much things, a bit anxious for them.

I trust that you are keeping well.

Respectfully yours,

W. Heasman Gibson
Ottawa, August 17, 1925.

Dear Mr. Gibson;

Salary is paid at the end of the September, December, March and June quarters, as soon as the school returns, properly certified by the Indian agent, reach the Department.

October 24th, 1933.

Sir,

On visiting the Noksilah Indian Day School today I found every seat in the classroom filled and two couples sitting together in a single seat, and I would like to apply for two No.3 desks, which the teacher thinks will be sufficient.

Now that the school is filled to capacity, the teacher finds that she is very short of blackboard space, and asks for two blackboards, nine feet by three, which I would like to recommend.

The stove in this school has been so badly located, being placed over in one corner, with the result that the children in the far end do not get the benefit of the stove that they should, and I had decided to move the stove out into the centre of the room, but in doing this it will require a sheet iron protector at a cost of about $3.00, which I would like permission to purchase, as it is absolutely necessary, otherwise the children near the stove would be too warm.

I regret having to report that the recent flood in the Cowichan river did considerable damage around the Koksilah Indian Day school. The foot bridge leading to the school which is of truss construction, partly washed out and will have to have repairs done to it, as one of the piers washed out completely. The bridge is 110 feet long, and I managed to get it propped up until such time as the water drops, so that work could be done on it, and as the water is now receding very fast, I have an Indian who says he can repair the same at a cost of about $25.00.

The school building itself leaked very badly, with the result that the water came in and made a bad mess of the walls, which together with the woodwork in the hall should be refinished and stained and the front steps require to be repaired and painted and the two toilets were almost completely demolished by the storm, and they will have to be partly rebuilt as well as shingled. As this building was put up in 1915 it is only natural that it will require some repairs, especially after weathering a storm like we had. I have estimated that it will take about $50.00 to cover the cost of repairs required around this school, that is provided the roof does not have to be reshingled.

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)

Sir:

I herewith beg to enclose two petitions from different Indians praying that the Department provide transportation for their children to the Koksilah and the Cowichan Indian Day Schools.

There are a number of children living at the Somence village, Cowichan Indian reserve, at Duncan, that go to both these schools. Reverend Father Neway and Mr. Neary, the teacher at Cowichan Day School have been transporting the children to the Cowichan Day School, but the other children that go the Koksilah Day school have had to walk, and in doing so have a dangerous railway bridge to cross over, as well as having a swollen River to contend with in the winter time, with the result that when the weather is bad the parents refuse to send them to school. The bridge is exceptionally dangerous, especially in snowy and frosty weather.

You will see from the petitions that there are 14 children for each of these schools, but five of those down on the list of the Cowichan Day School live at Quamichan, more than half way to the school. There are a number of other children at Clemolemaluts that do not attend school, that could be picked up, and thus augment the number stated in the petitions.

I have delayed in forwarding these petitions until I could get what I considered a fair offer to do the work. The Vancouver Island Coach Lines wanted between $7.00 and $8.00 per day, which would amount to over $140.00 per month; and Mr. Kyle who runs a Taxi service asked $120.00. I considered both these figures far too high.

You will see from Reverend Father Neway's letter that he and Mr. Neary have offered to do the work for $15.00 a piece, and I am enclosing a letter also from a Mr. W.H. Hawkins who has a bus, and he has offered to do the Koksilah school for $40.00 a month, or the two of them for $60.00. I consider this offer very fair and just, as this man would go right around, and thus pick up the children before mentioned at Clemolemaluts.

I think the time has come, in order to assure regular attendance that transportation should be provided, and I would be glad if the Department would give this matter favourable consideration.

Your obedient servant,

H. Graham,
Indian Agent.

I regret to say that I had to over expend by a few dollars the amount authorized—namely $75.00.

This school was built in 1914, and when we came to make repairs, we found things in a worse condition than we had expected. For instance, the two toilets had to be completely re-built, and the steps were in a worse condition than anticipated, and the walls of the school room were so badly stained that we had to give them two coats of kalsomine, all of which took time.

When I first reported on this building, the roof to me looked perfectly good, but after the shingles dried out, during the very hot weather, we examined the same, and found the whole south side was just like a sieve, you could see daylight through it all over, but this of course will take up to a certain extent in the wet weather, but I am much afraid that it is going to leak more or less in various places, and as this school has been built now 21 years, it is time for it to be renewed, and in order to make a proper job, the whole of the south side walls require to be done, and this would necessitate taking off the old shingles and replacing with new ones, at an estimated cost of about $50.00, and I would like to recommend if at all possible that this be done.

The rest of the school is now I think in a very creditable condition.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. K.

With reference to enquiry regarding Indian children being driven to Nanaimo Indian Day School, I wish to advise that this service was commenced in March, 1930. Previous to that time a number of children attending the Nanaimo School were transported free of cost by a mining company's train. The mine was closed in March, 1930, and the train discontinued. At that time the Department authorized the transportation of some ten children to the Nanaimo School whose homes were a distance of approximately six miles from the school. The amount allowed for this service is $60 a teaching month, or a total of $600 for the ten months in the academic year.

Last June, Mr. Agent Graham wrote the Department suggesting that transportation be provided for the children attending the Koksilah and Cowichan Day Schools. He states that the children living at a distance from both these schools could be transported to the schools each day at a cost of $60 a month. Owing to the fact that no provision had been made in our Appropriation for the fiscal year 1935-36 for this expenditure, Mr. Graham was advised at that time that the amount requested could not be provided. He was instructed to again communicate with the Department before the schools reopen on September 1, 1936, at which time it was decided to give the request further consideration.

Actg. Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your File 152-8-5.

I am forwarding herewith a copy of a letter received from Reverend Father Lauzon, S.M.M., regarding the transportation of pupils to and from the Cowichan Indian Day School. Father Lauzon refers to having discussed this matter with you during your visit to Duncan on June 3rd and 4th. I cannot at the moment recall having taken part in the conversation referred to.

The per capita rate for which Father Lauzon proposes to provide transportation for the Indian children is very reasonable when compared with the rates paid by the local School Boards for transportation of White children in the same area. Father Lauzon's application for authority to transport 30 children at $52.50 per month is recommended for favourable consideration.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONT.
Dear Major MacKay:

As you remember, Mr. Hoey at his visit in Duncan, said that if I was able to secure transportation for more children, he would be willing to increase the grant at the actual per capita rate.

Ever since I have tried to get a car, large enough to take ten children at the time. The car I have now the intention of buying was $995.00 till lately. But because they can not sell it, they are willing to let it go at $895.00.

My plan is to trade my Austin for that car. I would have to pay $100.00 over on the trade. Moreover I would have to spend about $25.00 to equip it according to regulation of the Motor Act.

Here is what I propose to you to be submitted to the Department. At the actual rate per capita, it would amount to $52.50 a month for 30 children. A total for the 9 months remaining of the school year, of $472.40.

Besides after receiving a hint from a friend that the Traffic Department were quite exacting this year, I inquired indirectly, and the result is that I have my doubt as to whether or not I would be allowed to transport the children in my little car. Last year I was told although not by the police Department, that I could do it without any permit as long as it was not for commercial purposes. But now I am told that anyone receiving remuneration of any kind to transport children must have a permit from the Police Department. And I am nearly sure at least according to the written regulation that they would not allow me to take 5 children at the time in the Austin. Most probably I would have to cancel the transportation.
Now this new car I intend to take is a seven passenger Plymouth. The Police Department has seen it and will allow me to carry ten children at the time. I will have all licenses required and the insurance covering a school bus for ten children.

The program will be to take ten children to Koksilah School. I will pick ten more on my way back to the Cowichan School, passing by the lower part of the reserves, and then I will make another trip towards Duncan to get the children I am now transporting.

I would like to start the first week in October. So if there is anything to settle see to it. As long as I get the grant of $52.50 a month I will agree.

I know that it is quite late; but I did not hear about this offer before this week. Could you ask for the answer by wire so that I can put the deal through at the end of next week.

Yours always,

"Father X Lauzon."
S.M.M.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant you may purchase the oil sprayer at a cost not exceeding $4.10.

Due to present conditions it is impossible to increase the amount allowed for janitor services at Indian day schools. At many Indian schools the older boys and girls assist with the sweeping and the boys especially can look after the fires. All such work can be done under the supervision of the teacher. Sir:

In reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, I would like to advise that I consider that the oil sprayer requested by Miss Perry, the teacher of Kokoilah Indian Day School should be supplied. They have been endeavoring to put the oil on the floor with a fly tox sprayer, which is much too light and will not function with the oil; so I would like to strongly recommend that a proper oil sprayer be authorized.

It is noted that you advise that it is not considered necessary to authorize the $5.00 applied to have the school cleaned and scrubbed, as janitor services are already paid for at this school. $2.50 per month is allowed to cover the janitor work, which is a nominal sum which covers the daily sweeping and dusting and tending of the fires, but could hardly be expected to cover the annual cleaning and scrubbing.

As a thorough cleaning and scrubbing is so necessary for health and sanitation which we try to stress to the Indians, I would like to strongly recommend that this expenditure be authorized.

Your obedient servant,

(R. H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I beg to forward herewith an application received from Mr. Indian Agent Moore for authority to expend the sum of $24 on repairs to the roof of the Koksilah Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

During a recent inspection of the Koksilah Indian Day School, it was noted that the roof was leaking around the chimney and along the eves; upon investigation it was found that it would take about 2000M shingles to make the necessary repairs as well as a sheet of tin for flashing around the chimney and some nails. I estimate that the total cost including the labour will be in the neighbourhood of $24.00.

I trust that you can see your way clear to authorize this expenditure, with the least possible delay, as a great deal of damage to the inside is likely to happen unless speedy action is taken.

Yours obediently,

(R. H. Moore)

Dear Sir:

Mr. Indian Agent Moore has applied for authority to purchase a wood burning circulator heater for the Koksilah Indian Day School. There is a small box stove in use at present which does not heat the classroom properly.

I visited this school recently and found that the front of the room and the area in the immediate vicinity of the stove were too warm, while the temperature in other parts of the room registered 60 degrees. A circulator heater is necessary for this room, and I would recommend that same be provided. A suitable heater can be secured here for approximately $40.00.

Dear Sir:

You will please remember our recent visit to the Koksilah Indian Day School and the broken down steps which occurred the day we arrived. As instructed by you I proceeded to have the steps repaired but upon investigation I found that all the under-pinnings for the steps, including the whole frame, were so rotten that it was out of the question to try to repair the bottom step so I got a list of the necessary material required to put in new steps up to the School, which is the only way to make them safe as the whole set-up is likely to fall and hurt someone.

I beg to attach hereto in duplicate a list of the materials required and would advise that I got a price on the labour from Indian Joe Elliott who says that the new steps can be built in about three days and a half, which will cost $10.00. You will, therefore, see that the total cost will amount to $21.31.

Yours obediently,

(R. H. Moore)

Duncan, B.C.
October 17th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Ref: 1941-42 Estimates for Cowichan Agency.

In connection with the above mentioned subject, I beg to refer you to an amount of $155.00 for repairs to the Koksilah School.

In making a recent inspection of the repairs that will be necessary to this school this year, I believe that we will be able to get away with new shingles and stain for same. The roof is leaking very badly in places and on close inspection of the cause I find that the shingles were not stained and curled so badly that the water can almost pour in, there is also a nice growth of moss on the shingles near the peak of the roof on both sides which also helps to hold the water and allow it to run down between the shingles instead of over them.

The total estimated cost of the necessary repairs to this school is as follows:

| Item                                      | Cost   |
|-------------------------------------------|--------|
| Shingles                                  | $68.00 |
| Staining, removing old shingles and putting on new ones, labor & stain | $75.00 |

$143.00

"Please note that the labor on this job will have to be done by white carpenters as suitable Indian labor is not available."

This is practically the same work that was done at the Nanaimo Indian Day School and the sooner the work is authorised and taken in hand the better, otherwise the damage which will be done to the interior of the school may be considerable.

Yours obediently,

D.M. MacKey, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $8.00 for gravelling the road at the Koknilah Indian Day School. When forwarding the voucher, you should attach receipts from the persons to whom the payments were made.

Yours truly,

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith letter date the 13th instant received from Mr. Indian Agent Moore requesting authority to expend $8.00 for graveling on Cowichan Indian Reserve at the Koksilah Indian Day School, for work which has already been carried out in order to enable the school bus to turn at this point.

I can verify Mr. Agent Moore's statement that the road in this vicinity is too narrow to permit the school bus to make a turn without leaving the road when, of course, it is on soft ground and liable to get into difficulties. Consequently, I would recommend consideration of the application.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Enc.
Dear Sir:

During the month of December last, the condition of the Mission Yard at Koksilah was in very bad shape owing to the yard being used by the school bus to turn around in. This yard is the only place big enough to permit the bus to turn after it unloads the children going to the Koksilah School and picks them up again in the afternoon.

Mr Kinney asked me if the Department would arrange to have an Indian haul a few loads of gravel to dump where the actual turning round place was as it was really making a mess of the yard once it got off the actual driveway. I said that I would ask for the necessary authority and explain the situation to you and I felt that the request would be given favourable consideration.

The matter was overlooked, and the next thing I knew was that the gravel was down, Mr Kinney not having waited for the authority figuring I imagine that it would come through in due time. Then I found that he had paid the Indians himself as those who did the hauling did not want to wait, the result being that I considered the question of no immediate importance and so it got forgotten about. Now the time has come, when Mr Kinney is being moved away from the Koksilah Mission and has written me this morning asking if he could be refunded for having had the gravel hauled. The total amount involved is $5.00 which is really quite cheap when we consider that there were 13 yams of gravel actually delivered in the seven loads. If you can see your way clear to authorise this expenditure I will submit a voucher for the above amount in favour of Mr G. Kinney.

Yours obediently,

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Vancouver, B.C.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

The Secretary: Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

In explanation of the attached Voucher No. 746, amounting to $5.00 for clothing and some food supplies issued to two young women of the Cowichan Band, called Janet Williams and Geraldine Thorne for emergency labor at the Koksilah Indian Day School, I wish to advise that during a visit to that school in early December I found that it required a thorough cleaning, walls, windows and woodwork which were extremely dirty owing to excessive soot and other particles of dirt having collected through the interior of the school at the time the chimney was cleaned last November.

Ordinarily, the cleaning of a chimney should not cause this, but owing to the fact that this particular chimney had not been cleaned for at least 10 years everything was full and when the pipes of the stove were taken down soot and ashes flew all over the place. The Chimney Cleaner cleaned up the mess on the floor etc., but the walls, windows and woodwork were so dirty that I deemed it necessary to have it attended to right away. I trust my action having this attended to will be approved.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, September 27, 1943.

Mr. R. H. Moore, Indian Agent, Duncan, British Columbia.

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $3.50 a month for the current academic year to enable you to purchase material for the hot drink for the pupils at the Koksilah Indian Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

On behalf of the Koksilah Indian Day School,
I would like to ask for authority covering an expenditure
of $3.50 per month, for the current academic year,
covering purchase of materials for a hot drink for the
pupils at lunch time.

An expenditure of $2.75 per month has been in
effect for some years past, but it is found that with
the increase in cost of supplies and with the number of
pupils attending, that this is not sufficient, to cover
the cost of supplies, and I would recommend that $3.50
per month be authorized.

Major D.M. Mackay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of August 19 and also copy of a letter received by you from Mr. Indian Agent Moore sent forward therewith.

In view of the lateness of the season, immediate steps should be taken to have the repairs at these schools undertaken and completed at an early date. I agree with you, however, that the digging or deepening of a well at the Tsartlip School is a matter with respect to which we might secure more information from the Agent, which information might be sent forward to the Surveys & Engineering Branch.

May I again express regret that these repairs were not undertaken early in the vacation period. It is exceedingly difficult for me to understand how these repairs can be undertaken without resulting in great inconvenience to both teachers and pupils, unless they can be completed before September 1.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith a copy of a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Moore regarding repairs to certain Day Schools in his Agency, provision for which was made in the current year's estimates.

If funds have been provided, I would recommend that this work be undertaken with the exception of deepening the existing well or digging a new well at the Tsartlip Indian Day School, a project which should stand over until the matter has been investigated on the ground by the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

The Department's decision by air mail would be appreciated.

May 5, 1944.

The Departmental Purchasing Agent,-

The enclosed Special Category Application has been received in this branch from Mrs. Ruth Myrtle Miller, Teacher of the Koksilah Indian Day School, Koksilah Indian Reserve, who lives at Duncan, B.C.

Indian Agent Moore states in a letter to Indian Commissioner MacKay that Mrs. Miller, in the 10 months of the teaching year, travels approximately 2,775 miles in driving to and from the school. The pupils in the school are taken to and from the school in a bus, but Mrs. Miller has to be at the school when the pupils arrive and remain there until after they depart so that she cannot travel by the bus. She must, therefore, use her own car as she cannot walk.

The Indian Commissioner, through whose office the application was forwarded, has stated that Indian Agent Moore's support of the application and explanation as to the necessity for a special category for Mrs. Miller should justify certification of the application.

In addition to the regular travel in the performance of her duties as teacher, Mrs. Miller has to use her car for extra and special trips to the homes of parents in regard to absenteeism and sickness.

Mrs. Miller was furnished last year with an A ration book, but as she travels a minimum mileage of 3,000 miles as a teacher in reaching the school and in her other duties as teacher, it is thought that she should be granted sufficient gasoline to cover the 3,000 miles of travel.

I would ask that consideration be given to this application.

Director.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

I beg to forward herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of April 17th, letter of April 1st from Mrs. Ruth M. Miller, teacher of the Koksilah Indian Day School, and application from her for a Special Gasoline Ration.

There would seem to be some correspondence regarding certification of these Application forms, as the Regional Director - Gasoline Rationing - in a letter dated April 4th, 1944 stated:

"We have received instructions that all employees of the Department of Mines and Resources must have their Special Category applications certified in Ottawa by C. W. Jackson, Chief Executive Assistant."

Mrs. Miller is definitely a Departmental employee and any certification other than that of the Chief Executive Assistant would not be acceptable to the Oil Controller.

Mr. Indian Agent Moore's support of the application and explanation of the necessity for a Special Gasoline Ration for Mrs. Miller are, in my opinion, sufficient to justify certification of the application.

For D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
Mr. P. H. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Shuswap B.C.

Dear Mr. Moore,

Enclosed I am sending you my completed application for extra gas to carry on my work as a Rural Teacher at the Koksilah Indian Day School.

Last year I estimated my mileage on the basis of 75 miles per week, and that did not include the extra trips I must often make into the homes of the parents in regard to absentee sickness, etc. I was given last year an A Book which by being very careful I just took care I was needed as a teacher, as I stated above.

Yours Respectfully,

Mrs. Ruth M. Miller.
Duncan, B. C.
April 17th, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

I beg to attach herewith a letter, and copy of same, from Mrs R.M. Miller, Teacher of the Kekkilah Indian Day School, along with her application for a Special Gasoline Category, all of which I trust you will find self-explanatory.

I am at a loss to know just how to handle this request as I received a similar one from Sister Maureen Regan and sent it direct to the Department who replied under date of the 3rd. instant as follows:

"I return herewith the special category application of Sister Maureen Regan. It does not appear that this car is entitled to a special category. In any case there is no certificate on page 2 that could conscientiously be signed by any official of this Department. The only one at all applicable is No. 2, which should be signed locally by someone having personal knowledge of the facts deposed to on page 1."

Signed: "Harold W. McGill"

In view of the foregoing there would not appear to be any use in sending this application to the Dept. and it would also appear as if no one in this Department should sign any such application. However, who then could sign it that would have personal knowledge of the fact that Mrs Miller teaching in one of our schools and travels, according to my reckoning, approximately 2775 miles during the 10 months of school? It is quite true that a bus takes the pupils to and from this school but the teacher has to be there before the bus arrives and after it leaves so actually she has to travel by her own car, or walk, which she cannot do. Please advise in this regard just what procedure should be followed.

(R.H. Moore) Indian Agent.

I wish to thank you for your letter of the 16th ultimo, File No. 152-8A-1, authorising the purchase of a second hand organ for Komiskah Indian Day School. In this regard I wish to attach herewith three Vouchers covering the cost of the organ, tuning it, and having it moved to the school, amounting in all to $23.50.

I was fortunate in being able to get a suitable organ from the local United Church at a cost of $15.00. It had to be cleaned and tuned as it had been stored in a dusty hall for two or three years and then it had to be taken to the school. The cleaning and tuning cost $6.00 and the moving $2.50.

I thought that I made a pretty good buy when I got the instrument for $15.00 but didn't realise just how good until it was being cleaned when the tuner told the teacher that she had a good organ and that it was worth at least $40.00 or $50.00.

In conclusion permit me to express the thanks of the Teacher and pupils to the Department for making it possible for them to get this much needed instrument for their school.

(R.H.Moore)

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian agent Moore's letter of September 12th, with reference to work to be done at the Koksilah Indian Day School to improve the lighting in the classroom.

In the absence of any definite decision with respect to the removal of this School to the old Cowichan Indian Day School building and, in view of the fact that this building will likely be in use for some time, I would recommend that authority be granted for an expenditure not exceeding $25.00 for this purpose.

-HN
In reply to your letter, with enclosure I wish to advise that the work has been completed on the bridge across the creek and the job appears to be quite satisfactory. Vouchers for materials and labor will go forward in due course.

While on the question of this school, I wish to advise that I have just returned from there today and the teacher was asking about lights for the winter months. Even today, which is bright and sunny as any day in summer, it was quite dark and dull in the school building and not a bit of sunlight getting into the school room on account of the trees on the south side of the building.

From the point of view of light and sun, I would recommend that the trees on the south side of the building for a distance of 75' or so be slashed down to allow more light and sun to get into the room. I believe that this could be done for ten or twelve dollars and I would so recommend, and request that the necessary authority for this be issued as soon as possible. I would also request authority to have ten loads of gravel dumped in the Church yard where the bus has to turn around at an approximate cost of $10.00. You will understand that the Missionary is granting us a favor to permit the bus to turn in his yard and I feel that we should take ordinary precautions to see that it is not torn up and made muddy during the wet weather.

Re-Visit to Kosilah Day School,
Cowichan Agency.

1. The above school was visited on 22nd May.

2. The school was clean and tidy and the children were clean, reflecting a good control by the teacher, Mrs. R.M. Miller.

3. Drinking water is supplied from a well nearby and kept in an uncovered pail. The children have individual drinking cups but dip these into the water pail.

4. Toilets are outside and the excrement is collected in a box which is cleaned once a month. The boys' toilet was in a very uncleanly state.

5. It was noted that a United Church Mission Building close by had a large water tank and pump installed. The distance from school to water tower is probably just over a hundred yards.

6. It is recommended that the United Church of Canada be approached to ascertain if a water supply for the school could be made available from their source. Rev.W.P. Bunt, B.C. Superintendent of Missions, was contacted and is favourably inclined towards the suggestion.

7. It is further recommended that flush toilets be installed at the school, also sinks for wash-up and taps for a drinking water supply, or better still, a drinking fountain.

MEMORANDUM

To: Indian Commissioner for B.C.  
July 11, 1947.

From: Inspector of Schools.

Re - Use of Old Cowichan School -

I refer to Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of May 21st, 1947, concerning the transfer of the Koksilah School to the Cowichan School. I visited the latter when I was on Vancouver Island and I do not favour this move for the following reasons:

1. The windows in the Cowichan School do not provide adequate lighting.

2. A well or other water supply would have to be provided.

3. The cost of renovation of the old school would be considerable. The roof requires reshingling, the entrance porch is falling down, the interior would have to be painted.

4. The proximity of this school to St. Catherine might make available the vocational facilities at the latter school, but would be undesirable for other reasons. Unfortunately a comparison of the two schools is already made by the local Indians and bringing the two schools closer together would increase this tendency.

R.F. Davey  
Inspector of Schools.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

As you are aware we have for some time been considering the transfer of the Koksilah Indian Day School to the old Cowichan Indian Day School building, but had left the matter in abeyance pending an inspection by the School Inspector. School Inspector Dewey's Memorandum in this connection is enclosed herewith, and, in view of the information given, I would recommend against such a transfer. It is considered that the present Koksilah Indian Day School building would best serve the needs of the Indians.

If the Department concurs in this recommendation I should appreciate being advised if the amount of $400 entered in the current Cowichan Agency estimates is available for repairs to this building. I have no detailed information with respect to the repairs necessary, but will secure quotations and tenders on receipt of advice that the required funds are available.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Encl.
-ms.
Ottawa, July 14th, 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 12th instant. The Department agrees with you that the present Koksilah Indian day school should continue to be used. We note that Inspector Davey does not favour the transfer of the school to the old Cowichan day school building.

An amount of $400 will be allowed for repairs and improvements to the Koksilah School.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I am enclosing a requisition dated July 7th covering requirements at the above mentioned school. The items "window blinds" and "ring pulls" have been approved and arrangements have been made to secure the 10 small desks, the cost of these items to be met from the appropriations for this school, reference Mr. Neary's letter of July 14th.

I would also like to recommend that the allowance for janitor's services for this school be increased from $5.00 to $8.00 a month, which will bring it along the lines of the amount paid elsewhere, and is thought to be quite reasonable for the amount of work involved.

Mr. R. H. Moore,
Indian Agent.,
Duncan, B.C.

Dear Mr. Moore:

Reference your letter of July 29th, about being able to purchase water from the Mission supply.

I do not know who led you to understand that this was a possibility as I certainly have had no conversation with anyone, and neither has anyone approached me with regard to the matter, until I received your letter, so some one seems to have been speaking without any authority.

No; it would not be possible for us to enter into any arrangements such as you suggest, as we have no extra supply beyond that required by the Manse; and even if we had, you would experience the same difficulty, which we experience every winter, of having the pipes frozen for days at a time.

The solution of your problem, as it seems to me, is to have a proper well dug, with a pump affixed, as there is no difficulty in securing water here. The well would not need to be any more than 14 or 16 feet deep.

Yours very truly,

Signed: "Walter J. Challis"

Ottawa, November 21, 1947.

Mr. R.H. Moore, Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.

We have your letter of the 12th instant with reference to the request that you have received for increasing the allowance for purchase of materials for a hot drink for the pupils of the Koksilah Day School.

Owing to the payment of Family Allowances it is reasonable to suppose that parents are in a better financial position to provide food for the children and also to give them some lunch when coming to school.

The Department has not decreased the amount previously allowed for mid day lunch purposes but it is not our present intention to increase this allowance. It is quite possible that some children will bring sufficient lunch and consequently it should not be necessary to supply all with a hot drink.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

PP/MGD
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, ONTARIO.

Please refer to your above noted letter, authorizing the amount of four dollars ($4.00) per month to Koksilah Indian Day School with which to purchase materials for a hot drink for the pupils at noon.

I attach, herewith, copy of a letter received from the teacher, Mrs. R. M. Miller, in which she points out that this amount is only half enough to buy the necessary supplies to last out the month and is asking that double this sum be authorized.

Your consideration to this request will be appreciated.

Major D. M. MacKay is receiving a copy of this correspondence for his information.

R. H. MOORE
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6400, File 826-5, part 4)
Duncan, B. C.,
P. O. Box 557,
November 6, 1947.

Mr. R. H. Moore,
Indian Agent,
DUNCAN, B. C.

Dear Sir:

The amount of four dollars ($4.00) allowed to us to buy ingredients for hot lunches for the children at the Koksilah Indian Day School is not sufficient. I can buy only enough milk for half the month, and now that more new pupils have enrolled I also need more cocoa and sugar. During October I had to stop making hot drinks for them at the middle of the month, when my supply of milk was exhausted. I will have to do the same this month.

May I suggest the amount of four dollars be increased to eight dollars.

Yours truly,

Signed: "Ruth M. Miller"

(EL)

In explanation of the attached Voucher No. 1387, dated December 15, 1948, amounting to $15.00 in favour of Mr. G. D. Gamble, Victoria, covering the cost of repairs to the organ at the Koksilah Indian Day School, I would advise that the instrument — which is quite old and was bought second-hand, for twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the school about five years ago — simply refused to play just as the pupils were in the middle of their rehearsals for the Christmas Concert.

As there is no one locally to do repairs of this kind travelling tuners and repair men call here once every two months or so and it so happened that Mr. Gamble was in town a day or two after the organ failed so I asked him to take a look at it and, if only minor repairs were required, to go ahead and do them. This was done and the account rendered, which I would recommend be paid.

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Superintendent Moore's letter of January 4th in connection with a proposed expenditure of $64.00 for graveling the turn-around at the United Church Mission property for the school bus.

Mr. W. S. Arneil,

VANCOUVER, B. C.

Please refer to my letter of November 29th, 1946, and your reply, above noted, authorizing an expenditure of fifty dollars ($50.00) to pay for graveling the turn-around at the United Church Mission property for the school bus.

I was down there recently and was really ashamed of the condition the bus had made of these grounds this winter. There are holes and ruts eight to twelve inches deep and the width of dual wheels from the entrance to the grounds right down to the Missionary's garage where the turn-around is made.

I had a truck driver down there this morning to see how many loads of gravel will be required and we estimate it will take six or eight 4-yard loads to make a job of it. The charge will be eight dollars ($8.00) per load, spread, or a maximum of sixty-four dollars ($64.00).

May I have authority to have this work done, now, while the ground is frozen.

R. H. MOORE
Superintendent
Cowichan Agency

I have had a request from Mrs. R. M. Miller, teacher of the Koksilah Indian Day School, that her school room be thoroughly cleaned from top to bottom, during the holidays. She wants the walls cleaned off, windows and woodwork washed, and the floor scrubbed.

In spite of the fact that we pay Mrs. Miller five dollars ($5.00) per month for Janitor Services at this school during the ten months it is in operation, the fact remains that it requires a thorough cleaning at least once a year, which is certainly beyond the physical capabilities of Mrs. Miller to do, herself.

I realize that, if this is done at the Koksilah Indian Day School, the other teachers in our day schools are entitled to like consideration. Personally, I believe all day schools should be thoroughly cleaned during the holidays -- and not by the teachers as, in my opinion, they receive little enough now for the janitor work they do during the time school is in session.

Re: Koksilah Indian Day School

You will note from Superintendent Moore's letter of August 9 and enclosure attached, that an expenditure of $35.00 is necessary for repairs to the above-mentioned school building. Only $200.00 was specifically required in the estimates for this work, but the repairs detailed in Mr. Richardson's tender are apparently necessary, and I would recommend that Mr. Moore be authorized to have him proceed with the work.

W.S. Arneil
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
At the request of the Teacher at the above school I visited the building recently to check over on necessary repairs which are required before the school reopens. I was accompanied by Mr A.V. Richardson, local contractor, who went over the class room, desks, windows, doors etc., with me and finally came up with a list of necessary repairs which must be made this fall.

The attached quotation in duplicate covers the requirements and with the exception of renewing the floor in the front porch, and the damaged plaster in the school room plus a broken pane, the rest of the repairs were anticipated last year at the time the Estimates were submitted.

Renewing the plaster on the ceiling of the classroom is the big job and was not anticipated, but the "bats" which used to occupy the attic of the building in large numbers some years ago eventually took their toll on the ceiling plaster, so that with the continual wetting it became bulged and eventually is breaking away. The fact that this building is in such a dark location, without artificial light, requires a bright interior to permit the pupils to see the black boards, as well as to have sufficient light to read by.

I would recommend that authority be granted for these improvements at the earliest possible date. I know that I am late in getting this application in but I was unable to get a Contractor to take time off to even look at the job until last week end, although I have tried on many occasions.

R.H. Moore,
Superintendent.
Indian Department,
Duncan, B. C.

Attention Mr R.H. Moore,

Dear Sir:

Re your enquiry for repairs to Indian school at Koksilah; We are pleased to quote you the price of $325.00 for the following:

Renew front porch floor
Remove damaged plaster in school room and renew.
Supply and replace one broken pane of window glass.
Check all desks and tighten screws replacing those missing.
Set all desks on new one by three (1 X 3) runners.
Repair front door.
Paint all woodwork in classroom and vestibule, 1 coat oil paint.
Two coats of water paint on all inside walls and ceilings of class room and vestibule.

Yours truly;

A. V. RICHARDSON LTD.,

W. S. Arnell, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B. C., Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration, Vancouver, B. C.

RE: Vouchers #788 and #789 - made payable to Mr. Pat Mason and Evans Lumber Co.

The above-noted vouchers amounting to $47.20 and $56.65 respectively are attached hereto and cover material and labour incurred in the rebuilding of a small bridge and approaches in order to reach the Koksilah Indian Day School.

This bridge has been a source of trouble to me and the school teacher for a number of years. The school cannot be reached without it and every year during floods, two or three days of school have been lost due to the unsafe condition of the bridge.

This year, with the exceptional high water, the bridge floated downstream, about six feet, and came to rest on a tree. When the water receded the children were able to cross at the new location and school carried on. However, last week it was necessary to have fuel oil delivered to the school and the truck could not drive across and, consequently, the bridge had to be rebuilt.

The new bridge has been raised, is well bolted down and should not, under normal conditions, give us any further trouble. The accounts are very reasonable considering the amount of work involved, and I would recommend, with your approval, that they be paid.

Mr. Davey is aware of the condition of this bridge and could give you first-hand information should it be required.

R.H. MOORE,
Superintendent,
Cowichan Indian Agency.

W. S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B. C., Dept. of Citizenship and Immigration, Vancouver, B.C.

RE: Koksilah Indian Day School

I should like to have authority to stain the outside of the above-mentioned school and renew the eavestrough and downpipes.

I had not planned on any repairs for this school this year but I find the bats have been at work again and made a terrible mess of the windows and walls. To prevent a recurrence of this it will be necessary for us to put a galvanized tin shade under the eaves with a 12" projection - something after the style of a visor on the windshield of a car - so that the droppings and liquids may be kept away from the windows and side walls.

This is really a necessity and an item of $800.00 was included in the current year's estimates for this purpose, although I was going to try and get along without doing the work this year in view of the possibility of the closing of the school next year.

I had a rough estimate prepared and by keeping everything to a minimum including the use of brown stain for the walls instead of paint, I consider that we can have a satisfactory job done for $600.00.

A list of materials will be submitted later if I am assured of the work being done.

R.H. Moore,
Superintendent,
Cowichan Indian Agency.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. G. H. BARRY,
DISTRICT INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS, VICTORIA,
B.C., ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE KOKSIHLAH INDIAN
DAY SCHOOL ON JUNE 24th, 1937.

Having had a long talk with the teacher with
reference to the teaching of Vocational Subjects, Arts
and Crafts, Etc., I have to recommend that a small grant
of not more than one hundred dollars per year be given
to this school for the teaching of such Arts and Crafts
as can be arranged for by the Indian Agent and teacher.
I believe that the children could be taught to
make good baskets if a suitable Indian woman were
employed under the supervision of the teacher for one
afternoon per week during the period October to May.
This Indian should be a good basket maker,
and should if possible be also good in the making of
small articles out of the raw wool, which should be
spun, etc. in the school. Some blanket weaving should
be carried out.
Suitable pay for this instruction would be a
dollar per week, and some material would have to be
purchased. If the boys were supplied with one set of
simple tools they could make the weaving frames and
other necessary articles. With a fret saw and some three-
ply material they could start toy making which is the
first step in Manual Training.
The girls do sew at present as previously
reported, but I am anxious to have the children learn
basket making before this is a lost art here.
Indian Affairs Branch.

In Account with
